channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Florida’s Fort Myers Area, Scenes of Paradise May Be Lost for Good
item.description: On Fort Myers Beach, Sanibel Island and Pine Island, cherished landmarks and an easygoing existence were obliterated by Hurricane Ian.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Reed, Patricia Mazzei and Jack Healy
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue workers in Fort Myers Beach on Thursday.

item.title: Facing a Dire Storm Forecast in Florida, Officials Delayed Evacuation
item.description: A day of hesitation in Lee County came despite warnings that the Fort Myers and Cape Coral area could see mass flooding. Now authorities are encountering mass death.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles, Mike Baker, Serge F. Kovaleski and Lazaro Gamio
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tristan Stout, 22, surveying the damage to his father’s boat after it was moved across the street on San Carlos Island in Fort Myers Beach.

item.title: Hurricane Ian Descends on South Carolina, Swamping Beachside Towns
item.description: The storm, which had pummeled Florida, made landfall again in South Carolina, but with less fury than it had earlier in the week.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Fawcett, Kellen Browning and Rick Rojas

item.title: Putin Announces Ukraine Annexation, Calling West the Enemy
item.description: Declaring that Russia would annex four regions of Ukraine, which the West rejects as illegal, the Russian president accused the U.S. and its allies of “despotism’’ and “Satanism.’’
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia addressed a rally and concert in Red Square on Friday celebrating Russia’s illegal annexation of four Ukrainian provinces.

item.title: Biden Calls on World to Punish Russia for Attempt to Annex Ukrainian Land
item.description: The U.S. imposed new sanctions on Russian officials and companies, and penalized foreign businesses aiding the Russian military. But officials are holding back on energy sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
item.media:description: Residents casting their votes in a referendum in Donetsk, a province of eastern Ukraine that Russia has claimed as part of its territory.

item.title: Liz Truss’ Woes Multiply After Media Blitz
item.description: In a round of interviews, the prime minister showed little sympathy for the pain that high interest rates could inflict on mortgage holders, critics said.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss’s Conservative Party now trails the opposition Labour Party by 33 percentage points in polling.

item.title: Stock Market Ends an Ugly Quarter With Another Volatile Day
item.description: The S&P 500 has fallen for three consecutive quarters, the kinds of losses investors have not faced since 2009.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison

item.title: Trump Argues for Executive Privilege in Jan. 6 and Mar-a-Lago Inquiries
item.description: In both cases, former President Donald J. Trump is claiming a novel power to keep White House information from his time in office secret from the Justice Department.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage and Glenn Thrush
item.media:credit: Oliver Contreras for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump has claimed a broad interpretation of executive privilege in his legal battles since leaving the White House.

item.title: Congress Clears Stopgap Spending Bill With $12.3 Billion in Ukraine Aid
item.description: The House passed the bill before departing ahead of the midterm elections, and President Biden signed it hours before a funding lapse would have forced a government shutdown.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:description: Representative Rosa DeLauro, with President Biden at the White House Congressional Picnic in July, on Friday called the investments in the spending bill “urgent and necessary.”

item.title: Biden’s Plan for Student Loans Attracts Lawsuits, Scams and Confusion
item.description: As borrowers wait for the administration to unveil an application for loan forgiveness, they are wary of legal challenges and a proliferation of misinformation.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: The goal of President Biden’s student loan forgiveness program was to instantly improve the finances of millions of Americans. But the process has been chaotic.

item.title: Early Cormac McCarthy Interviews Rediscovered
item.description: The Pulitzer Prize-winning author has done vanishingly few interviews during the course of his career. In these early ones, some newly uncovered, he is less guarded.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth A. Harris
item.media:description: Cormac McCarthy at his writing desk in Blount County, Tenn., as printed in the Maryville-Alcoa Times on Feb. 26, 1971.

item.title: N.F.L.’s Concussion Protocol Under Scrutiny After Tagovailoa Injuries
item.description: The N.F.L. said its concussion protocols were followed when Tua Tagovailoa hit his head on Sunday. On Thursday, the quarterback left the field on a stretcher after a second head hit.
item.dc:creator: Ken Belson
item.media:description: Tua Tagovailoa’s injury Thursday, in a game against the Cincinnati Bengals, was the second time in a week that he appeared to sustain a head injury.

item.title: After Paramedic’s Killing, Detectives and Neighbors Grasp for a Reason Why
item.description: The 34-year-old suspect was described as a loner who struggled with his mental health, but had given no hints that he would do harm.
item.dc:creator: Michael Wilson
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hundred of firefighters and emergency personnel salute an ambulance carrying the body of Lt. Alison Russo-Elling.

item.title: Alison Russo, Stabbed NYC EMT, Was the ‘Mother of the Station’
item.description: Lt. Alison Russo-Elling had served nearly 25 years, through Sept. 11 and the Covid pandemic. She loved a tough job enough to volunteer in her free time.
item.dc:creator: Corey Kilgannon
item.media:credit: Ahmed Gaber for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fire Department officers embrace at a memorial bunting ceremony at the lieutenant’s station Friday.

item.title: Can Smartphones Help Predict Suicide?
item.description: A unique research project is tracking hundreds of people at risk for suicide, using data from smartphones and wearable biosensors to identify periods of high danger — and intervene.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Kayana Szymczak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Katelin Cruz uses a phone and FitBit to submit data about her mood and other metrics to Harvard researchers studying suicidal tendencies. “I think it’s almost easier to tell the truth to a computer,” she said.

item.title: Wendell Pierce Steps Into ‘Death of a Salesman’
item.description: A Broadway revival of “Death of a Salesman” has a Black lead for the first time, giving Pierce a chance to step into a role he was “born to play.”
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.media:credit: Nate Palmer for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I have to know and feel that lead coat, the heaviness and the weight of the world that is placed upon Willy so that I can fight with all the fire and exuberance,” Wendell Pierce said of his approach to the role.

item.title: Putin Is Turning Russia Into a Giant North Korea
item.description: He has set in motion forces that are turning Russia into a giant North Korea.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman

item.title: Big Tech Should Support the Iranian People, Not the Regime
item.description: Western technology companies, recently freed from sanctions, should grant full access to Iranians.
item.dc:creator: Mahsa Alimardani, Kendra Albert and Asfaneh Rigot

item.title: The Supreme Court Is Broken. Where’s Biden?
item.description: Why is the president sitting this out?
item.dc:creator: Jeff Shesol

item.title: If Bolsonaro Loses Brazil’s Election, Will He Respect the Result?
item.description: Brazilians are holding our breath.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Barbara
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: A man in a shirt with the image of Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, who is seeking to regain Brazil’s presidency, in Rio de Janeiro on Sunday

item.title: A Strong Dollar Is Hurting Other Countries. Should the Fed Care?
item.description: Experts disagree.
item.dc:creator: Peter Coy
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; images by CSA Images, via Getty Images

item.title: How the Remote Work Craze Made Housing Affordability Worse
item.description: How the affordability crisis got even worse.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; images by Tom Werner and GCShutter, via Getty Images

item.title: Why China’s Crimes in Xinjiang Cannot Go Unpunished
item.description: China is dragging the world back to a human rights dark age. It’s time to push back.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bequelin
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen and Lauren Hard
item.media:description: Ian became a tropical storm over the Carolinas two hours after making landfall.

item.title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
item.description: Our TV critic recommends a vampy adaptation, a surprising rap drama and the astonishing return of “Ramy.”
item.dc:creator: Margaret Lyons
item.category: Anne Rice's Interview With the Vampire (TV Program)
item.media:description: Jacob Anderson stars in the new adaptation “Anne Rice’s Interview With the Vampire.”

item.title: A Times Climate Event: Can Technology and Art Inspire Change?
item.description: Hear from business leaders like Laurene Powell Jobs and John Doerr, along with storytellers and food innovators in a livestreamed Times event in San Francisco.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Are Your Patients Worried About the Polio Vaccine?
item.description: We want to hear from you.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Gabler and Sheera Frenkel

item.title: Military Officers Announce Coup in Burkina Faso
item.description: The officers said they had decided to remove the president because of his inability to stem a growing Islamist insurgency in the north and east of the country.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Elian Peltier
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Crowds gathered in protest of the country’s president, Lt. Col. Paul-Henri Sandaogo Damiba, in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, on Friday.

item.title: United Airlines to End Service at J.F.K. Airport
item.description: The airline said it was too small to compete at the airport and would cease flights there at the end of October.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.media:description: In the year ending in September, United operated fewer than 3,000 flights in and out of Kennedy Airport, accounting for less than 1 percent of airport traffic there.

item.title: The Worst Foods and Drinks for Your Teeth
item.description: When assessing how likely a given meal, snack or drink is to harm your dental health, there are two main things to consider, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Seo
item.media:credit: Kelsey McClellan for The New York Times

item.title: Is Seltzer Water Just as Healthy as Flat Water?
item.description: Unsweetened carbonated water is a better choice than soda or fruit juice. But don’t overdo it, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: If Food Is Love, My Kids Must Hate Me
item.description: Growing up, I equated great meals with a healthy family dynamic. My children couldn’t care less.
item.dc:creator: Chaunie Brusie

item.title: Can You Get Over a Food Intolerance?
item.description: Foods most often associated with intolerances were chocolate, food additives, citrus fruits, fish, shellfish, milk, cheese, eggs and nuts.
item.dc:creator: Richard Klasco, M.D.

item.title: Why Negan and Maggie Aren’t Ready to Leave ‘The Walking Dead’
item.description: As the zombie drama rounds out its final season, the longtime co-stars Jeffrey Dean Morgan and Lauren Cohan will reunite for the spinoff “Dead City.”
item.dc:creator: Calum Marsh
item.category: The Walking Dead: Dead City (TV Program)

item.title: How to Solve Intermediate Crosswords
item.description: Moving up to the Wednesday and Thursday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
